Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: Preparing the Next Generation of Computational Thinkers: Transforming Learning and Education Through Cooperation in Decentralized Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project's aim is to understand collaboration, cooperation, and learning in the context of a large, distributed virtual organization consisting of children and teachers building web-based simulations and animations using the Scratch software. The PIs will study the nature and patterns of cooperation in the Scratch decentralized learning environment, establish principles to guide the development of systems that foster cooperative attitudes and behaviors, and develop strategies to cultivate computational-thinking capacities that are important for productive cooperation and problem-solving in virtual organizations. The Scratch community consists of over 400,000 registered members discussing, remixing, and reusing more than a million projects. The project is a collaborative project with researchers from MIT, Harvard, and the University of Pennsylvania drawn from computer science, psychology, child development, education, organizational science, and economics.

Using a novel combination of experimental and ethnographic methods, the research will provide insights into how young people cooperate in virtual organizations, their attitudes and motivations related to cooperation, and their development of computational-thinking skills and capacities necessary for productive cooperation and creative learning. The researchers expect that the findings will contribute to the design and understanding of more effective virtual organizations, particularly in the areas of learning, education, and cooperative creation. The methods used include observational studies, design interventions, and field experiments. The test bed will be the Scratch community and the evaluations will be done by mining the online record of cooperation in the construction of new simulations and animations.

The outcomes of the project will include an improved Scratch environment, design principles for the construction of distributed virtual organizations that encourage cooperation and co-construction of knowledge and artifacts, and new methods of teaching computational thinking in an engaging environment. The Scratch community of 400,000 members will be part of this work. This project is potentially transformative because of the engaging nature of this particular application, because of its applicability to similar virtual communities, and because of its promise to reach a diverse community of learners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research grant focused on the ways that new forms of collaboration can foster and support the development of computational thinking. As an experimental testbed for our observational studies, we used the NSF-funded Scratch learning network, where young people (ages 8 and up) program and share interactive stories, games, animations, and simulations, using a specially- designed graphical programming language. All activities and resources on the site are available free of charge. The Scratch learning network now has more than 9 million registered members, sharing more than 12 million projects and posting more than 62 million comments online.

We designed and implemented a series of online collaborative challenges that had some classes of high school youth participating face-to-face. We had three collab challenges where youth were asked to design animations, stories or music videos, by organizing themselves into groups with others. We varied contexts for participation, examined the role of feedback on project revisions, and provided project structures to enhance group work and increase programming complexity. To complement these intervention studies, we conducted backend data analysis using a random sample of 5,000 users that logged into the site January - March 2012 and examined their levels of computational participation. Here we focused on the changes over time in Scratch members’ use of  various networking features such as project comments, downloads, and likings. We also examined use of different programming concepts in relation to account age and gender. Finally, we conducted studies that moved computation and collaboration beyond the screen. In a series of six pilot studies conducted over three years, we worked with middle and high school youth on projects that integrated Scratch game design with tangible design via a popular construction kit, MaKey MaKey. In these latter studies, we saw collaboration manifest in new ways-students sharing ideas, helping each other with code and engaging in peer feedback. Thus by expanding the modalities and reshaping the projects, we provided new ways for youth to engage in collaboration that was embedded within a larger computational context.

In terms of intellectual merit, we found that (1) online collaboration and complexity of programming benefitted from providing feedback on projects in progress; (2) about ten percent of Scratch members are highly engaged over time with few of the newcomers moving into more advanced forms of online networking and programming; (3) differences in programming were based not only on account age (not surprisingly) but also on gender with girls’ programs on average having fewer complex scripts; (4) diversity in project content and creators is lacking; and (5) game designs beyond the screen offer promising opportunities for students, alone or together, to engage with computational thinking concepts, practices and perspectives.

In terms of broadening participation our research illustrates the ways in which collaborative programming activities can not only bring newcomers into the online community but also engage oldtimers in meaningful mentoring activities. While the percentage of active Scratch members is far higher than observed in comparable youth online communities, we observed significant gender differences in terms of program complexity. The use of tangible materials opened up additional modes of engagement for younger users. These findings suggest that Scratch programming and community is successful in reaching a large number of novice programmers but still requires further support in broadening participation to newcomers and underrepresented groups.
